author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Public Theater Takes Shakespeare in the Park Out on the Town
description: The Delacorte Theater is being renovated, so a musical version of “The Comedy of Errors” is touring some of the city’s outdoor spaces.
content: On a small stage, three actors practiced a sword fight — slowly, then faster. Behind them board operators ran a sound check and a wardrobe assistant shook out costumes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Mark Abramson
title: San Diego Is Once Again a Top Migrant Entry Point
description: Asylum seekers from around the world are trying to enter the United States through California, and immigrant traffic there has reached its highest level in decades.
content: From sunrise to sunset, the U.S. Border Patrol buses arrived every hour at a sunbaked parking lot in San Diego.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Modi Will Feel the Heat in a Third Term. And Not Just Politically.
description: Farmers have repeatedly protested over grievances tied to global warming, a major political and economic test given the importance of India’s rural economy.
content: India, the world’s most populous country, is also among the most vulnerable to climate hazards. That’s not only because of the heat and floods that global warming has exacerbated, but also because so many of the country’s 1.4 billion people are vulnerable to begin with. Most people are poor, by global standards, and they have no safety net.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: To Restrict Migrants, Biden Leans on Trump’s Favorite Immigration Law
description: President Biden’s executive action addresses one of his most serious political vulnerabilities ahead of the presidential election.
content: Looking for a way to shut down the southern border in 2018, President Donald J. Trump found a 73-word provision in the asylum law that he said gave him “magical authorities” to keep migrants out of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Reich
title: How Did Cats Take Over the World? One Bizarre Drawing at a Time.
description: In “Catland,” Kathryn Hughes has a theory about our obsession with our feline friends — and one cat lover in particular.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Ex-Agent Who Criticized F.B.I. to Congress Has Security Clearance Reinstated
description: Marcus Allen was also awarded back pay and resigned from the bureau after reaching a settlement agreement, his lawyer said.
content: A former F.B.I. agent who criticized the bureau in congressional testimony has been awarded back pay and had his security clearance reinstated, his lawyer said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli
title: Modi Struggles to Stay on Top: 4 Takeaways From India’s Election
description: The prime minister will keep his job, but his aura has been diminished and his leadership has fundamentally changed as the country’s multiparty democracy springs back to life.
content: Narendra Modi’s first decade as India’s prime minister came with its fair share of surprises. None, however, looked anything like what happened on Tuesday morning when he won his second re-election, but lost his party’s majority in Parliament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz
title: How Biden’s Asylum Order Works
description: The president issued an executive order that essentially blocks asylum claims at the southern border, a major shift in how the United States has handled claims for protection.
content: President Biden announced an executive order on Tuesday to essentially block asylum at the southern border, a major shift in how the United States has historically handled claims for protection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein and Anna Kodé
title: Feud Erupts Over the Prospect of a New Hamptons Nightclub
description: Scott Sartiano proposed bringing his Manhattan-based members-only hot spot, Zero Bond, to a historic village inn. Local residents are not rolling out the red carpet.
content: Whether it’s complaints about air traffic at the East Hampton airport, teenagers partying on the beach or the arrival of Uber and Lyft drivers, the controversies that dominate the news cycle on the East End of Long Island, N.Y., are usually about one thing: noise — and who, in a place where residents are used to getting nearly everything they want, is allowed to make it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli
title: India’s Stock Market Tumbles on Close-Run Election Result
description: A bull run came to an abrupt end when Narendra Modi’s party fell short of expectations.
content: Traders in Mumbai started the day with a shock as India began tallying votes from a seven-week election and it became clear that the government of Narendra Modi was not doing nearly as well as expected. By the end of trading on Tuesday, the markets were down 6 percent, nearly wiping out the year’s gains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Marco Hernandez
title: Devastation in Ukraine
description: Measuring every town, street and building blown apart since the Russian invasion.
content: Imagine your hometown being wiped off the map.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: F.D.A. Panel Rejects MDMA-Aided Therapy for PTSD
description: An independent group of experts expressed concerns that the data from clinical trials did not outweigh risks for treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder.
content: An independent advisory panel of the Food and Drug Administration rejected the use of MDMA-assisted therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder on Tuesday, highlighting the unparalleled regulatory challenges of a novel therapy using the drug commonly known as Ecstasy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli
title: How Modi Capitalized on India’s Economic Rise
description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi inherited a big and growing economy, kept it going and worked to put his imprint on every aspect of its success.
content: Ten years after Narendra Modi was first elected prime minister, India’s economy is roughly twice as large. That is what happens when a country grows at 7 percent a year, as India has been doing, on average, since it opened its markets to international competition in 1991.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Restaurant at Bedford Post Reopens With Tavern Fare
description: Nomad Tea Parlour offers dim sum and takes on Chinese American specialties, Veselka opens an outpost in Williamsburg and more restaurant news.
content: When post roads were horse and buggy interstates, the Bedford Post Inn, dating from 1762, was a rest stop. Its gracious restaurant is now reopening after renovations with the chef Sam Mason turning out tavern fare like oysters, onion tart, skirt steak and grilled chicken, not just his usual pastries. Like the rest of the inn, Sunday Hospitality, which also runs El Quijote and Cafe Chelsea in Manhattan, is managing it in partnership with the actor Richard Gere, an owner. Bedford Post Barn, a casual spot on the property for all-day fare and baked goods from BreadsNbakes nearby, is opening soon. (Opens Wednesday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: In Israel and Ukraine, Biden Navigates Two of America’s Most Difficult Allies
description: President Biden has promised to support the two countries for as long as it takes. Both their wars appear to be at critical turning points.
content: Over the past five days, President Biden has been engaged in a very public demonstration of the struggles of managing two of America’s most difficult allies, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, both leading countries that the president has vowed to defend, as long as it takes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: The Republican Party’s Decay Began Long Before Trump
description: In the past, the G.O.P. could’ve prevented a candidate like Donald Trump from running. But Daniel Schlozman and Sam Rosenfeld argue the party structure has been “hollowed out” over the years.
content: After Donald Trump was convicted last week in his hush-money trial, Republican leaders wasted no time in rallying behind him. There was no chance the Republican Party was going to replace Trump as their nominee at this point. Trump has essentially taken over the G.O.P.; his daughter-in-law is even co-chair of the Republican National Committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Woman Declared Dead Is Found Alive at Funeral Home
description: Constance Glantz, 74, of Lincoln, Neb., was pronounced dead in a nursing home. A funeral home employee preparing her body realized that she was breathing.
content: A Nebraska woman who was pronounced dead at a nursing home on Monday was discovered breathing hours later by a funeral home employee, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Transplanted Pig Kidney Is Removed From Patient
description: The organ, from a genetically modified animal, failed because of a lack of blood flow, surgeons said, but did not appear to have been rejected by the body.
content: Surgeons removed the kidney of a genetically engineered pig from a critically ill patient last week after the organ was damaged by inadequate blood flow related to a heart pump that the woman had also received, according to officials at NYU Langone Transplant Institute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie J. M. Baker
title: ‘There Is No Ethan’ Is a Jaw-Dropping Tale of Digital Deception
description: Reading Anna Akbari’s memoir of online manipulation, you think you’ve seen it all — then you keep reading.
content: I did not expect to be shocked by “There Is No Ethan.” Online deception has become so ubiquitous that it’s boring. By now, the term “catfish,” which was added to the Merriam-Webster dictionary a decade ago, seems almost quaint. But the twists and turns in Anna Akbari’s book are outrageous. I read it in one sitting, then spent days recounting her story to anyone who would listen, unable to shake off my indignation on behalf of the author and her fellow victims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: The-Dream, Hitmaker for Beyoncé and Rihanna, Is Accused of Rape
description: In a lawsuit, a former protégée of Terius Gesteelde-Diamant says he entangled her in an abusive relationship. Mr. Gesteelde-Diamant called the allegations “untrue and defamatory.”
content: Terius Gesteelde-Diamant, a top songwriter and producer for Beyoncé, Rihanna and other stars under the name The-Dream, has been accused of rape and sexual battery in a lawsuit filed on Tuesday by a former protégée.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Mexico’s new president.
content: Claudia Sheinbaum, a climate scientist and a former mayor of Mexico City, will be Mexico’s next president after a landslide victory in the country’s election. She will be the first woman, and the first Jewish person, to hold the post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: Everything You’ve Been Told About Birds Is a Lie
description: Peter McIndoe and Connor Gaydos aim to turn an online caper into a full-fledged book.
content: Birds are, in fact, real.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Michael Gold
title: Fingers Point as Biden Closes Border to Asylum Seekers
description: The president blamed Donald Trump and Republicans for the failure of a previous immigration plan. Mr. Trump called the new action too little, too late.
content: At the beginning of his remarks from the White House on Tuesday announcing that he would prohibit migrants from seeking asylum at the U.S.-Mexico border, President Biden tried to make clear just whose fault it was that he was taking action by executive order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: To Make a Hit Los Angeles Restaurant, ‘Vanderpump’ It
description: The most hotly anticipated opening in the city this year might be a sandwich shop from two Bravo stars.
content: The fans control everything in the “Vanderpump Rules” multiverse, and lately what the fans want are crisp, pressed turkey sandwiches and prebiotic sodas under the soft glow of shabby-chic chandeliers in West Hollywood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Brother Marquis, Member of Rap Group 2 Live Crew, Dies
description: Born Mark Ross, he was a well-known member of the group, which fueled a debate about artistic freedom.
content: Brother Marquis, a member of the Miami hip-hop group 2 Live Crew, whose sexually explicit lyrics prompted a debate about race and artistic freedom in the 1980s and ’90s, has died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Lots and Lots
description: Daniel Bodily takes a hands-off approach.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova, Constant Méheut and Aric Toler
title: Ukraine Strikes Into Russia With Western Weapons, Official Says
description: The official said Ukraine had destroyed missile launchers in the Russian region of Belgorod using an American-made rocket system.
content: Just days after the Biden administration granted permission for Ukraine to fire American weapons into Russia, Kyiv took advantage of its new latitude, striking a military facility over the border using a U.S.-made artillery system, according to a member of Ukraine’s Parliament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Wednesday Briefing: Modi’s Bruising Path to a Third Term
description: Also, a Times analysis of the destruction in Ukraine.
content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India claimed a third term in office yesterday. But early results suggest his party won by a far narrower margin than expected. The aura of invincibility around Modi has been shattered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Counts Down to Donald Trump’s Sentencing
description: Colbert showed off his “Countdown to Sentencing Advent Calendar,” which contained a bottle of bourbon.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: At 70, Cyndi Lauper Has Nothing Left to Prove
description: She’s plotting a farewell tour. She’s starring in a documentary about her life. And she could only ever be herself.
content: One Friday afternoon in May, Cyndi Lauper stepped out of her Upper West Side apartment building and into the streets of New York City. She wore glitter-encrusted glasses, sneakers with rainbow soles and a stack of beaded bracelets on each arm. A rice-paper parasol swung in her hand. As she walked, she examined the crowds and remarked when glints of interest caught her eye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Baker and Judson Jones
title: A Year After Orange Skies Covered N.Y.C., Residents Get Another Air Quality Alert
description: This time ozone, not smoke, was to blame.
content: Nearly a year after orange smoke from Canadian wildfires enveloped New York City, residents received text messages Tuesday morning about a different kind of air quality alert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: As Mexico Elects Claudia Sheinbaum, the Departing President Begins His Farewell
description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, who has been a defining figure in Mexican politics, has said he will retire to a family ranch after his term ends. Some expect his influence will continue.
content: Sunday was a historic day in Mexico, with a landslide election victory for Claudia Sheinbaum, the first woman and first Jewish person to become the country’s president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Danny Hakim
title: Wisconsin Charges 3 Trump Allies in Fake Electors Scheme
description: It is the fifth battleground state to prosecute former President Donald J. Trump’s supporters for trying to overturn his defeat in the 2020 election.
content: Wisconsin brought felony charges on Tuesday against three onetime advisers of former President Donald J. Trump in connection with a fake electors plot there in 2020, becoming the fifth battleground state to prosecute his allies for their attempts to overturn his defeat that year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Rwanda’s 2024 Election: What to Know
description: President Paul Kagame led Rwanda out of the genocide, but has since dominated the country like a colossus. He is running for a fourth term after winning three elections.
content: Rwanda’s presidential and parliamentary elections this year are taking place three decades after the genocide in which some 800,000 people were killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: The Low-Key British Newshound Taking Charge of The Washington Post
description: Robert Winnett is virtually unknown in the U.S. and keeps a low profile in his native Britain, too. This fall, he will oversee the newsroom of Woodward and Bernstein.
content: In the swashbuckling world of British newspapers, the editor Robert Winnett stands out for his lack of flash. Taciturn and low key, more likely to be buried in documents at his desk than hobnobbing at a Mayfair club, Mr. Winnett, the deputy editor of The Daily Telegraph, is known for his focus on breaking news, once earning the nickname “Rat Boy” for his relentless drive for scoops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: As China’s Internet Disappears, ‘We Lose Parts of Our Collective Memory’
description: The number of Chinese websites is shrinking and posts are being removed and censored, stoking fears about what happens when history is erased.
content: Chinese people know their country’s internet is different. There is no Google, YouTube, Facebook or Twitter. They use euphemisms online to communicate the things they are not supposed to mention. When their posts and accounts are censored, they accept it with resignation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: OpenAI Insiders Warn of a ‘Reckless’ Race for Dominance
description: A group of current and former employees is calling for sweeping changes to the artificial intelligence industry, including greater transparency and protections for whistle-blowers.
content: A group of OpenAI insiders is blowing the whistle on what they say is a culture of recklessness and secrecy at the San Francisco artificial intelligence company, which is racing to build the most powerful A.I. systems ever created.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in June
description: The final season of “Sweet Tooth” and a Richard Linklater rom-com highlight this month’s slate.
content: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of June’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Hermes
title: Margo Guryan Died in 2021. Her Music Keeps Getting Rediscovered.
description: “Words and Music,” a new anthology, shines light on a little-known but increasingly beloved master of pop and jazz songwriting.
content: In the late summer of 1970, Elton John arrived at Los Angeles International Airport for his debut U.S. shows and was greeted by another wildly talented piano-playing singer-songwriter: Margo Guryan. Her husband, David Rosner, worked for the company that signed John, and together they helped him get sorted in the run-up to his legendary performances at the Troubadour, kicking off a long, spectacular career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal, Alex Travelli, Hari Kumar, Suhasini Raj, Sameer Yasir, Pragati K.B. and Atul Loke
title: Needing Help to Stay in Power, Modi Loses His Aura of Invincibility
description: Though Narendra Modi will take up a third term as India’s leader, the election was closer than expected, forcing him to rely on coalition partners that don’t share his Hindu nationalist agenda.
content: Suddenly, the aura of invincibility around Narendra Modi has been shattered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Coleman
title: A ‘House of the Dragon’ Party Without a Silvery Wig in Sight
description: At the Season 2 premiere of HBO’s “Game of Thrones” prequel, the cast mingled over cocktails as early clips from the series suggested that “war is coming.”
content: Where does the story pick up this season on HBO’s fantasy epic “House of the Dragon”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Walker Mimms
title: Philip Guston’s Teenage Drawings Reveal a Lost World of Funny Pages
description: A fresh crop of apprentice cartoons — now public property — from his pen at The Junior Times may add to our understanding of Guston and his art.
content: Before Philip Guston developed the loud and plush figuration of his renown, before he Anglicized his surname in adulthood, the 12-year-old known as Philip Goldstein joined the art staff of the Los Angeles Times Junior Club.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Nonny Hogrogian, 92, Honored Illustrator of Children’s Books, Dies
description: A two-time Caldecott Medal winner, she brought multiculturalism to children’s literature by evoking her Armenian heritage.
content: Nonny Hogrogian, an illustrator who mined her Armenian heritage to bring diversity and wonder to her woodcuts and watercolors — an approach that helped expand the world of children’s literature and made her a two-time Caldecott Medal winner, died on May 9 at a hospital in Holyoke, Mass. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: After Trump’s Conviction, House Republicans Vow Again to Target His Foes
description: Speaker Mike Johnson announced a “three-pronged approach” for how Republicans on Capitol Hill would push back against the prosecutions of the former president.
content: House Republicans have spent the past 18 months vowing to use their majority to attack what they claimed was a “weaponization” of government against conservatives, including the prosecutions of former President Donald J. Trump, but have made little headway in doing so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Jez Butterworth’s ‘The Hills of California’ to Open on Broadway
description: The play, about a group of English sisters who reunite at their mother’s deathbed, plans to open in New York in September. It ends a London run this month.
content: “The Hills of California,” the latest darkly comedic drama from the acclaimed English playwright Jez Butterworth, will transfer to Broadway this fall after a well-received five-month run in London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: This D-Day, Europe Needs to Resolve to Get Its Act Together
description: People, and nations, succeed or fail to the extent that they refuse to hand over responsibility for their fates to others.
content: Thursday’s D-Day anniversary — the 80th — is occasioning somber and anxious reflections about the fate of the Atlantic alliance. Somber because the last of the Greatest Generation will soon no longer be with us. Anxious because Donald Trump, and his evident disdain for that alliance, may soon be with us again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa B. Jacoby
title: The Moral Limits of Bankruptcy Law
description: Companies are increasingly using the bankruptcy process to shortchange the rights of those seeking accountability for corporate wrongdoing.
content: When Purdue Pharma filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in 2019, it had over a billion dollars in the bank and owed no money to lenders. But it also had the Sacklers, its owners, who were eager to put behind them allegations that they played a leading role in the national opioid epidemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Halsey Reveals Illness in New Song, Saying They Are ‘Lucky to Be Alive’
description: The pop star shared that they had been diagnosed with lupus and a rare T-cell lymphoproliferative disorder.
content: An album, a new song and a medical diagnosis — the singer Halsey took to social media to announce them all.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘We Met at a Gay Bar Called Woody’s’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: In a movie, a twangy guitar riff would have played. I was a longtime lone ranger with debilitating social anxiety after moving from New Jersey to Tokyo and back again. She was a sandy-haired palomino mare who had become a therapist for traumatized veterans. The kicker? She, herself, had suffered prolonged abuse, becoming averse to human touch. We stood tall, eyes locked. The more I wrangled for her to like me, the further she cantered away. Then, one night, I rested my forearms on the fence and she approached me for the first time, dipping her nose to my palm. — Saachi Subramaniam
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: University of the Arts President Resigns After School Announces Closure
description: Kerry Walk announced last week that the institution would close on June 7, leaving hundreds of students in academic limbo.
content: The University of the Arts president, Kerry Walk, has resigned only a few days after her administration said that the nearly 150-year-old institution in Philadelphia would close because of declining revenue and enrollment, union officials representing school employees told The New York Times on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Meet the One Man Everyone Trusts on U.K. Election Nights
description: Prof. John Curtice, a polling guru with a formidable intellect and an infectious smile, has contributed to Britain’s TV election coverage since 1979.
content: When Britain votes in a general election on July 4, one person will likely know the outcome before anyone else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Poser
title: Ibram X. Kendi Faces a Reckoning of His Own
description: In 2020, the author of “How to Be an Antiracist” galvanized Americans with his ideas. The past four years have tested them — and him.
content: Ibram X. Kendi has a notebook that prompts him, on every other page, to write down “Things to be grateful for.” There are many things he might put under that heading. First and foremost, his wife and two daughters, and his health, having made it through Stage 4 colon cancer in his 30s — a diagnosis with a 12 percent survival rate. Tenure at Boston University, where Martin Luther King Jr. earned his doctorate in theology. A National Book Award, and a MacArthur “genius” grant for “transforming how many people understand, discuss and attempt to redress America’s longstanding racial challenges.” Then there were the millions of people who bought “How to Be an Antiracist,” the first of five of his books to take the No. 1 spot on the New York Times best-seller list. But he was particularly grateful to the readers who wrote to him to say his work changed them for the better.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Cracks Emerge in Hard Right Across Europe
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 4, 2024.
content: “Isn’t it paradoxical for a nationalistic party to team up with parties across their borders?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: In Red Montana, Two Democrats Take a New Political Approach: Attack
description: Democrats in Republican states have tended toward soft-spoken moderation, but Ryan Busse and Raph Graybill have charted a different course in trying to take down Gov. Greg Gianforte.
content: At a recent campaign event at a brewpub in Whitefish, Mont., Ryan Busse was laying into his political opponent, Montana’s Republican governor, Greg Gianforte, with surprising vehemence for a red-state Democrat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: For Heroes of D-Day, This Reunion Might Be a ‘Last Hurrah’
description: It is 80 years since the Allied invasion of Normandy, and the average age of veterans hovers at 100. Once they are gone, how will their sacrifices be remembered?
content: For many, it will be the last big commemoration. The last reunion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Linguine With Zucchini, Corn and Shrimp is Superbly Summery
description: As are lomo saltado, and a snap pea and herb salad with spicy peanut sauce.
content: What does summer taste like? Is it the salty snap of a hot dog? The creamy balm of strawberry ice cream? The tart-sweet burst of a handful of blueberries?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Theodore Schleifer
title: Can Bill Ackman Cash In on His Growing Fame?
description: The billionaire investor’s profile has soared on social media. That could help him grow Pershing Square, his financial empire.
content: Bill Ackman has gained new prominence in recent months for his outspoken presence on social media. But he has also made riches for his investors and himself — and now others are hoping he’ll continue to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Goodbye Inflation, Hello Recession?
description: The landing is almost here, but will it be soft?
content: Long ago I studied international economics with the great Charles Kindleberger, famous not just for his insights but also for his bon mots. One line I took to heart — he was talking about the balance of payments, but it applies equally well to many subjects in economics — was that people always want a single number, but what they really need is a story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Rival U.K. Political Leaders Clash in Bad-Tempered Election Debate
description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, fighting to narrow a substantial polling gap, adopted an aggressive approach against his Labour Party opponent, Keir Starmer.
content: The two contenders to become Britain’s next prime minister clashed angrily over tax, immigration and health policy on Tuesday in a televised debate that at times descended into ill-tempered exchanges as the political rivals talked over each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nouf Aljowaysir
title: I Asked A.I. Where It Thought I Was From. Its Answer: Nowhere.
description: In this short film, the visual artist Nouf Aljowaysir examines a question she’s struggled with since childhood.
content: Before I first moved to the United States at 13, my identity was simple: “I am from Saudi Arabia.” But as I got older, answering the question “Where are you from?” became increasingly complex. Because of school and family, I was constantly shifting between the two countries, never fully settling in one place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: empathetic
description: This word has appeared in 155 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word empathetic has appeared in 155 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 3 in “How to Survive Your High School Reunion” by Jancee Dunn:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsey Tramuta
title: This Summer in Paris: More ‘Open’ Signs, Thanks to the Olympics
description: With millions of visitors expected in the city, restaurant and shop owners are hoping they made the right decision to forgo their cherished annual vacations.
content: Anyone who’s visited Paris in late July and August knows the word “fermé.” It adorns the darkened windows of chic indie boutiques and cozy bistros whose owners, along with other locals, have fled the city on their annual vacations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Before a Debate, the U.K. Election Campaign Just Got Messier
description: The surprise candidacy of Nigel Farage, a Trump ally and architect of Brexit, unsettled a stagnant campaign before a first TV debate Tuesday night.
content: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and Keir Starmer, the leader of the opposition Labour Party, will square off on Tuesday evening in their first debate of Britain’s general election. But it is a third man, Nigel Farage, who has seized the spotlight in a race defined, until now, by a fading incumbent and a rising opponent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: House Democrats Begin Bid to Force Contraceptive Vote, Pressuring G.O.P.
description: By starting a discharge petition on legislation to codify the right to contraceptive access, Democrats aim to spotlight Republican opposition to the bill, part of a broader push to highlight the issue for voters.
content: House Democrats on Tuesday went on the offensive on reproductive rights, announcing they will seek to force a vote on legislation to codify the right to birth control access nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker
title: Visiting Europe, Biden Will Find Both Solidarity and Isolation
description: The president arrived in France for a visit meant to mark the 80th anniversary of the D-Day invasion and showcase Western unity. But even as he rallies American allies in defense of Ukraine, he will defy them on the war in Gaza.
content: As President Biden visits France this week, he will be rallying European leaders to his side and showcasing the resolve he has helped to foster on behalf of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Ron Edmonds, 77, Whose Camera Captured the Shooting of Reagan, Dies
description: Working for The Associated Press, he won a Pulitzer Prize for his sequence of photos showing the president being struck by a bullet while three others fell wounded.
content: Ron Edmonds, a photographer for The Associated Press who won a Pulitzer Prize for a dramatic series of pictures of the attempted assassination of President Ronald Reagan and the takedown of the gunman outside a Washington hotel in 1981, died on Friday in Falls Church, Va. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Sean Combs Sells Stake in Revolt, the Media Company He Founded
description: After a wave of lawsuits accusing Mr. Combs of sexual assault, the two are “completely separated and dissociated from each other,” the company’s chief executive said.
content: Sean Combs, the hip-hop mogul who has been facing mounting legal scrutiny over allegations of sexual and physical abuse, has sold his majority stake in Revolt, the media company that he founded, the organization announced Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: The Verdict Is In on the Supreme Court
description: It’s corrupt, rotten and hurting America.
content: After Donald Trump was found guilty of 34 felony counts in a Manhattan court, conservatives — from Marjorie Taylor Greene to George Santos to the Heritage Foundation — began posting upside-down American flags on X in solidarity with the “political prisoner,” as Trump absurdly styles himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Biden Goes After Trump’s Felon Status at Connecticut Fund-Raiser
description: Democrats had been clamoring for the president to ratchet up his criticism of his predecessor.
content: President Biden, prodded by Democrats to confront former President Donald J. Trump head-on about Mr. Trump’s criminal conviction in his New York hush-money case, heeded those calls on Monday night during a big-dollar fund-raiser in Connecticut for his re-election campaign and for the party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Both Democrats and Republicans Embrace Border Politics
description: Also, India’s election was closer than expected. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Republicans in Arizona voted this afternoon to put a measure on the state’s ballots in November that would make illegal immigration a state crime. If passed, the measure would give local authorities the power to arrest, jail and deport unauthorized migrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: Louisiana Passes Surgical Castration Bill for Child Sex Offenders
description: The bill, if signed by the governor, would be the first state law to allow a judge to order surgical procedures for those who commit sex crimes against children.
content: When State Representative Delisha Boyd of Louisiana read news reports in early May that a man accused of raping a 12-year-old girl was already a registered sex offender who had previously assaulted a 5-year-old, she said she couldn’t help but think about her own family: Her mother carried trauma for much of her life after being raped by a family acquaintance at age 15.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Trading Glitch Sends Some Shares on a Wild Ride
description: Berkshire Hathaway showed a drop of 99 percent before trading was halted and the technical problem corrected.
content: For about two hours on Monday morning, trading in shares of about 40 stocks on the New York Stock Exchange was halted after a technical glitch led to misquoted prices, including those of Berkshire Hathaway, which showed a drop of more than 99 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: The Big Hurdle Between R.F.K. Jr. and the Debate Stage (It’s Not a Poll)
description: The independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has said he’s confident he will qualify. But CNN’s rules have put an urgently ticking clock on his already-critical ballot access efforts.
content: President Biden’s campaign has been clear: He will debate former President Donald J. Trump only one-on-one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Estrin and Joshua Barone
title: At This School, the Students Live Entirely for Music
description: For a year, we followed five Curtis Institute of Music students as they made friends, pushed their artistry and stared down an uncertain future.
content: Delfin Demiray had packed too much. She was leaving her home in Ankara, Turkey, for the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia. An 18-year-old who had never been to the United States, she didn’t know what to expect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Khan
title: The Cookbook That Helped Me After a Divorce
description: “Indian Delights” connected me to a place I thought I’d left behind.
content: During the early stretches of the pandemic, when the rest of the world was preoccupied with sourdough starters, dalgona coffees and ways to use up the  dozens of eggs they’d hoarded from Instacart, I fished a neglected cookbook out of a box and set it on my counter. With a recipe for “Hot Water Pastry (Very Quick and Easy)” on Page 198 of the esteemed “Indian Delights” open before me,  I struggled to coax a mound of dough into gossamer wisps of pastry shell. As I pummeled the dough into submission, a dusting of flour settled on the book. I’m no baker, as evidenced by the water bottle I commandeered as a rolling pin. There was a brand-new package of pastry dough sitting in my freezer, just within reach, and yet my chalky onslaught continued.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: What Is MDMA Therapy and What Are Its Risks?
description: An F.D.A. advisory panel dealt a setback to those seeking treatment for PTSD, citing health risks of the illegal drug and study flaws.
content: The Food and Drug Administration is weighing whether to approve the use of MDMA, also known as Ecstasy, for treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: A Reporter Whose Beat Blends Sports and Culture
description: Emmanuel Morgan is enticed by how athletes and sports leagues are increasingly dipping into music, television and other media.
content: When Emmanuel Morgan was hired as a sports reporter covering the N.F.L. and combat sports for The New York Times in 2021, the job felt familiar. After all, Mr. Morgan, who grew up playing football, had been writing about the sport since high school. He went on to cover the N.F.L. for The Los Angeles Times for nearly two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hari Kumar, Mujib Mashal and Mike Ives
title: Modi’s Party May Need Partners to Form a Government
description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi is on track to secure a third term, but a dip in his party’s electoral support will have political consequences.
content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s ruling party will likely need help from junior partners to form a government under the rules of India’s parliamentary system, early election results indicated on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: Immigration Measure Added to the Ballot in Arizona
description: Republicans are hoping a proposal revisiting some of the tough immigration policies of a decade ago will turn out their voters.
content: Republican lawmakers in Arizona voted on Tuesday to put a ballot measure before voters in November that would make unlawfully crossing the border from Mexico a state crime. The proposal would give local police officers the power to arrest and jail unauthorized migrants, and would allow state judges to order deportations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Mujib Mashal, Yousur Al-Hlou, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and James Shield
title: Biden’s Asylum Order, and India’s Surprisingly Close Election
description: Plus, the scale of destruction in Ukraine.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Students Want Charges Dropped. What Is the Right Price for Protests?
description: At pro-Palestinian demonstrations, students have broken codes of conduct and, sometimes, the law. But the question of whether and how to discipline them is vexing universities.
content: Youssef Hasweh expected to receive his diploma from the University of Chicago on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Rob Burrow, Rugby Star and A.L.S. Campaigner, Dies at 41
description: The “Mighty Atom” enjoyed a glittering professional career in Britain before gaining more acclaim for his charity efforts after a diagnosis of motor neuron disease.
content: Rob Burrow, a rugby standout who overcame his diminutive stature with fleetness and ferocity to become an eight-time champion of Britain’s Super League and who was later hailed for raising awareness of motor neuron disease after being diagnosed with it in 2019, died on Sunday. He was 41.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: How Nurses Known as ‘Black Angels’ Helped Save TB Patients
description: An exhibition honors the hundreds of Black nurses who cared for tuberculosis patients in the mid-20th century after white nurses fled a Staten Island hospital.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at an exhibition about Black nurses who were recruited to care for tuberculosis patients in the mid-20th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: House Votes to Impose Sanctions on I.C.C. Officials Over Israel Prosecution
description: The Republican-written bill, which the White House strongly opposes, stands little chance of becoming law after lawmakers failed to reach a bipartisan deal on penalizing measures.
content: The House voted mostly along party lines on Tuesday to impose sweeping sanctions on officials at the International Criminal Court in a rebuke of efforts by the court’s top prosecutor to charge top Israeli leaders with war crimes in connection with the offensive against Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: PTSD Treatments Are Falling Short for Many Patients
description: Therapy and medication can help people recover from trauma, but many struggle to access the care they need.
content: Post-traumatic stress disorder closes people off. They withdraw — often reluctant to talk about what they’ve experienced and unable to trust others or themselves. But many leading treatments for the condition require just that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Wendell Pierce Claims Discrimination in Trying to Rent a Harlem Apartment
description: The renowned character actor, best known for playing Detective Bunk Moreland on HBO’s “The Wire,” says a white landlord rejected his rental application.
content: The acclaimed actor Wendell Pierce says his rental application for an apartment in Harlem was denied by a white landlord, and he believes racism is the reason.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: When Hydropower Runs Dry
description: The struggle of the world’s largest source of renewable last year could have important implications for the fight against climate change.
content: Global pollution from electricity generation was set to fall last year, thanks to the growth of renewable energy. Then came the droughts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 360, June 5, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: The Ultimate Charli XCX Primer
description: Prep for the arrival of her new album, “Brat,” with 11 songs from her catalog (and 10 bonus tracks!).
content: I don’t think there’s a single song I’ve listened to more over the past few weeks than “360,” the endlessly quotable, deliriously catchy synth-pop song by one of my favorite working pop stars, Charli XCX.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: Biden’s Crackdown on Migrants Reflects a New Reality for Democrats
description: Advocates of the right to asylum can’t defend the system when it’s broken.
content: There’s no denying that the executive order President Biden signed on Tuesday — significantly curtailing the number of asylum seekers allowed into the country — is a head-spinning reversal for a president who promised to undo Donald Trump’s policies at the border. It’s worth remembering that Biden wasn’t alone on that front. Eight out of 10 Democrats running in the presidential primaries said in 2019 that they would make walking across the border without permission a civil infraction, like a traffic ticket, instead of a criminal offense.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Psychiatry and the Dangerous Patient
description: Two psychiatrists respond to a Science Times article. Also: Dr. Fauci’s grilling in the House; a shortage of immigration lawyers; presidential rankings.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Early Election Results Suggest Sharp Turnaround for Indian National Congress
description: India’s beleaguered main opposition party was on track to surpass expectations and nearly double its share of parliamentary seats from 2019.
content: In India’s last general election, in 2019, Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party won 303 of 543 parliamentary seats — nearly six times as many as the main opposition party, the Indian National Congress. It was a stinging electoral blow for the Congress, a once-dominant party that has appeared greatly diminished in recent years, and exit polls in this year’s election had not suggested it would fare much better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: A Queer Coming-of-Age Tale, Set in a Brutal Anti-Gay World
description: In the novel “Blessings,” by Chukwuebuka Ibeh, a gay Nigerian boy works to understand himself in a country that’s increasingly hostile to people like him.
content: A decade ago, Nigeria freshly criminalized homosexuality. In the mostly Muslim north, the maximum penalty for even a suspected gathering of queer people became death by stoning; in the Christian south, over a dozen years in prison. The country has a deep-rooted culture of persecuting its gay citizens, but recent years have been something like a reign of terror against Nigeria’s L.G.B.T.Q. community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: ‘Bad Boys: Ride or Die’ Review: Older, but Never Wiser
description: In their latest buddy cop movie, Will Smith and Martin Lawrence are still speeding through Miami. The franchise has rarely felt so assured, relaxed and knowingly funny.
content: Two years after Will Smith slapped the comedian Chris Rock on the Academy Awards stage, it feels bizarre that he needs a franchise called “Bad Boys” to rekindle his star power. Smith and his co-star, Martin Lawrence, are two producers of “Bad Boys: Ride or Die,” the stylishly chaotic lark by the directors Adil El Arbi and Bilall Fallah, suggesting outsize roles as star-auteurs and the importance for this installment to be a hit. In their hands, “Bad Boys: Ride or Die” throws everything at the wall, and much of it sticks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Hamed Aleaziz
title: In Shift, Biden Issues Order Allowing Temporary Border Closure to Migrants
description: The move shows how drastically immigration politics have shifted in the United States. The American Civil Liberties Union said it planned to challenge the order in court.
content: President Biden issued an executive order on Tuesday that prevents migrants from seeking asylum at the U.S.-Mexico border when crossings surge, a dramatic election-year move to ease pressure on the immigration system and address a major concern among voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Maria Cramer
title: Senator Menendez Enjoyed a Steakhouse Dinner, as the F.B.I. Watched
description: At Senator Robert Menendez’s bribery trial, an investigator described surveilling diners at a Washington restaurant. Among them were Mr. Menendez and an Egyptian official.
content: The man and the woman arrived at the Washington steakhouse one evening in May 2019 and took a table on the patio, near where five diners already were seated and seemed to be enjoying themselves. Jackets were off, laughter was heard and wine was being poured. A cigarette dangled from one man’s hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Glenn Thrush
title: Garland Rebukes Attacks on Justice Dept. and Defends Refusal to Turn Over Biden Tape
description: The attorney general warned Republicans that their attacks were baseless and feeding “heinous threats of violence.”
content: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland, facing the prospect of a contempt vote in Congress, on Tuesday denounced attacks on the Justice Department by former President Donald J. Trump and his allies, including one he labeled a “conspiracy theory” and others he called “baseless and extremely dangerous falsehoods.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,082, June 5, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colleen Hamilton
title: We’re Entering a Joyful New Era of Lesbian Fashion
description: Pairing silky garments with butch suiting, women are pushing back against stereotypical ideas about dressing, on the red carpet and beyond.
content: Earlier this year, the actress Kristen Stewart appeared on the cover of Rolling Stone in a pocket-covered black leather vest that looked like it had been swiped from a 1980s lesbian bar. Bare-chested, her hair cut into a squirrelly mullet, she wore only one other garment: a white jock strap into which her hand plunged suggestively past the wrist. The 34-year-old former ingénue — who entered the public eye in 2008 as the teenage star of the “Twilight” movie franchise, before coming out in 2017 — seemed to be reclaiming pleasure exclusively for herself. For other appearances to promote “Love Lies Bleeding,” her A24-produced queer thriller, which was released in March, she channeled a similar spirit, showing up in a sea green Dickies bomber jacket over a stomach-baring crop top at the Sundance Film Festival and a structured black leather blazer with a fishnet bra on “Late Night With Seth Meyers.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Sam Rosenfeld and Daniel Schlozman
description: The June 4, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Sam Rosenfeld and Daniel Schlozman. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Family Discovers Rare T. Rex Fossil in North Dakota
description: Two brothers, their father and a cousin were hiking in the North Dakota Badlands in 2022 when they found the bones of a juvenile Tyrannosaurus rex.
content: In the summer of 2022, two boys hiking with their father and a 9-year-old cousin in the North Dakota badlands came across some large bones poking out of a rock. They had no idea what to make of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Eileen Sullivan and Zach Montague
title: Prosecutors Use Hunter Biden’s Memoir to Narrate His Spiral Into Addiction
description: Jurors at his trial in Delaware heard long clips from the audiobook of his memoir recounting events surrounding his purchase of a handgun in 2018. He is charged with lying on a federal form to buy it.
content: The first day of testimony in Hunter Biden’s trial on gun-related charges kicked off Tuesday with the surreal sound of the defendant’s own voice ringing through the courtroom, narrating his descent into drug addiction, when prosecutors played the audiobook of his memoir.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Gizmodo Sold to European Media Company
description: The tech website’s publisher, G/O Media, sold Gizmodo to the digital media and tech company Keleops.
content: The tech website Gizmodo has been sold to a European media company, the latest brand from the publisher G/O Media to go out the door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Garrett M. Graff
title: Why We Must Keep the Memory of D-Day Alive
description: What we’ll fight for is who we are.
content: Day by passing day, the Greatest Generation is coming toward its end. D-Day, June 6, 1944, had more than two million Allied personnel on the move across Operation Overlord, and today perhaps a few thousand veterans remain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: A Developing Heat Wave Will Be a ‘Shock to the System’
description: Inland parts of the state are expected to reach triple-digit temperatures this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Bensinger and Charles Homans
title: Epoch Times Executive Accused of Laundering $67 Million
description: Weidong Guan was charged with three counts in a scheme that the Justice Department said caused revenue to surge for the company, which has promoted Donald Trump and conspiracy theories.
content: A top executive at The Epoch Times, a right-wing media company, has been arrested and charged with laundering at least $67 million in stolen money through company accounts in a multiyear scheme to lift financial returns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Muhammad Ali’s Childhood Home Goes on the Market
description: The boxing champion lived in the one-story house in Louisville, Ky., which in recent years became a museum. It’s listed for sale, along with two neighboring properties, for $1.5 million.
content: The childhood home where Muhammad Ali, the three-time world heavyweight boxing champion and activist, learned to box and that was along the route of his funeral procession in Louisville, Ky., is for sale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bilal Shbair, Hiba Yazbek, Adam Rasgon and Michael Levenson
title: Gazans Pin Hopes on New Truce Proposal, but Remain Skeptical
description: A cease-fire plan described by President Biden has stirred cautious optimism after nearly eight months of war in the Gaza Strip.
content: After eight months of devastating bombardment by Israeli forces, some Gazans are urging Hamas to accept a cease-fire plan outlined by President Biden, but many remain deeply skeptical that the United States, as Israel’s chief ally, would truly bring an end to the war.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 4, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, June 4, 2024.
content: An article on Monday about the reopening of the New York City Section 8 vouchers waiting list misstated the name of a housing organization. It is New Destiny Housing, not New Destiny Project.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Andrew E. Kramer, Nina Feldman, Clare Toeniskoetter, Rob Szypko, Diana Nguyen, Michael Simon Johnson, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop, Sophia Lanman and Chris Wood
title: A Conversation With President Zelensky
description: In a wide-ranging interview, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine challenged the West’s hesitations.
content: Five years ago, a TV personality and comedian, Volodymyr Zelensky, won the presidency in Ukraine in a landslide victory. When Russia launched a full-scale invasion of the country three years later, he faced the biggest challenge of his presidency and of his life. Despite initial success beating back one of the world’s largest armies, the tide has turned against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Climate Group Is Running Ads on Biden Policies in Wisconsin and Michigan
description: The group, which has ties to Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington, has a $1 million plan for TV spots playing up the president’s record on green power.
content: A climate group with ties to Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington State is running $1 million of television advertising in Michigan and Wisconsin that aims to highlight President Biden’s record on renewable energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leavitt
title: In Drizzly England, a Tale of Sex, God and Celestial Bodies
description: In the latest novel from the “Essex Serpent” author Sarah Perry, astronomy and religion collide with unrequited romance under gray British skies.
content: No country takes as much pride in its own dismal climate as England. In “Enlightenment,” Sarah Perry’s aggressively English new novel, the word “weather” appears 50 times. Twenty-two times, including in the opening sentence, the weather is “bad.” Once it is “stormy,” once “unsettled,” once “disrespectful,” once “troubled” and once “English” (“the nothingness of English weather”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Sweeney
title: Spray Sunscreen Is Convenient. But Does It Work?
description: Dermatologists explain the benefits — and drawbacks — of this popular option.
content: Q: I use spray sunscreens all summer because they’re so easy to put on. But are they as good as lotions?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paige McClanahan
title: Why You’ll Pay More and Behave Better When You Travel This Summer
description: From Barcelona to Bali, higher fees and new rules are targeting overtourism and unruly behavior. Some locals are worried the changes will keep tourists away.
content: A new tourist fee in Bali. Higher hotel taxes in Amsterdam and Paris. Stricter rules on public drinking in Milan and Majorca. Ahead of the summer travel season, leaders in many tourist spots have adopted measures to tame the tourist crowds — or at least earn more revenue from them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Alec and Hilaria Baldwin and Their 7 Children Get a Reality TV Series
description: “We’re inviting you into our home,” the actor, who is set to stand trial next month on an involuntary manslaughter charge, said as he announced a show about his family on TLC.
content: Speaking with Alec Baldwin on her podcast last year, the talk show host Kelly Ripa made a pitch for him and his wife: “When I think about you and Hilaria and your seven young kids — now, I know what you’re going to say, but just go with me — this has reality TV written all over it,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘The Acolyte’ Review: ‘Star Wars’ an Even Longer Time Ago
description: The franchise’s latest series on Disney+ is set before there was even an empire to strike back.
content: “The Acolyte,” the latest product off the Lucasfilm assembly line (it premieres Tuesday night on Disney+), enters territory unfamiliar to the casual follower of “Star Wars.” It is set during a prehistorical period known as the High Republic, until now depicted primarily in short stories, novels and comic books read only by serious fans. (The High Republic stories are to George Lucas’s central works somewhat as “The Silmarillion” is to “The Hobbit” and “The Lord of the Rings.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Healy, Adrian J. Rivera and Frank Luntz
title: ‘Antihero’ or ‘Felon’: 11 Undecided Voters Struggle With How to See Trump Post-Verdict
description: The group discusses the trial, the verdict and its possible influence on the 2024 election.
content: The group discusses the trial, the verdict and its possible influence on the 2024 election.

author: By Brad Plumer and Nadja Popovich
title: As Solar Power Surges, U.S. Wind Is in Trouble
description: A 2022 climate law was expected to set off a boom in renewable energy. So far, that’s only come partly true.

author: By The New York Times
title: Garland Says He ‘Will Not Be Intimidated’ by House Republicans
description: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland, testifying before the House Judiciary Committee, defended the Justice Department against false accusations made by former President Donald J. Trump and his congressional allies.
content: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland, testifying before the House Judiciary Committee, defended the Justice Department against false accusations made by former President Donald J. Trump and his congressional allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff, Rebecca Suner and Christina Shaman
title: What to Know About Claudia Sheinbaum, Mexico’s President-Elect
description: Claudia Sheinbaum’s list of accolades is long: She has earned a Ph.D. in energy engineering, participated in a United Nations panel of climate scientists awarded a Nobel Peace Prize and governed Mexico’s capital, one of the largest cities in the hemisphere. On Sunday, she added another achievement to her résumé by becoming the first woman elected president of Mexico.
content: Claudia Sheinbaum’s list of accolades is long: She has earned a Ph.D. in energy engineering, participated in a United Nations panel of climate scientists awarded a Nobel Peace Prize and governed Mexico’s capital, one of the largest cities in the hemisphere. On Sunday, she added another achievement to her résumé by becoming the first woman elected president of Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Shawn Paik
title: How Modi Courted India’s Youth
description: India’s Prime Minister Narendra Modi tapped influencers and gamers to draw in young voters, many of whom are discontent with the economy and unemployment.
content: India’s Prime Minister Narendra Modi tapped influencers and gamers to draw in young voters, many of whom are discontent with the economy and unemployment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marco Hernandez and Nikolay Nikolov
title: How We Tracked Every Damaged or Destroyed Building in Ukraine
description: This is the first comprehensive map showing the destruction of the war in Ukraine. Using detailed analysis of years of satellite data, it shows every building that has been damaged or destroyed since Russia attacked in 2022.
content: This is the first comprehensive map showing the destruction of the war in Ukraine. Using detailed analysis of years of satellite data, it shows every building that has been damaged or destroyed since Russia attacked in 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Issues Order to Curb Immigration at Southern Border
description: President Biden’s executive order prevents migrants from seeking asylum at the U.S.-Mexico border when crossings surge.
content: President Biden’s executive order prevents migrants from seeking asylum at the U.S.-Mexico border when crossings surge.
